docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''A Judge's Plea for Pot'' (Op-Ed, May 17):

headline.main: Legalizing the Use of Medical Marijuana

docs.snippet: Readers react to an Op-Ed essay by a judge who says use of marijuana for easing pain should be legal.

docs.lead_paragraph: Because the mutations are so rare, costly studies involving large numbers of patients would be needed to identify their role in each disease.

headline.seo: Rare Genetic Mutations May Underpin Diseases
headline.main: Many Rare Mutations May Underpin Diseases
headline.print_headline: Rare Genetic Mutations May Underpin Diseases

docs.abstract: Two studies in journal Science finds that very rare genetic mutations may underlie common human diseases like schizophrenia and cancer, making it far more difficult for geneticists to discover their genetic roots; findings dim the promise of personal genomics curing disease.
docs.snippet: Because the mutations are so rare, costly studies involving large numbers of patients would be needed to identify their role in each disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: The same degenerative brain disease found in football players and boxers has been found in veterans exposed to roadside bombs, a finding with potentially profound implications.

headline.seo: Brain Disease Is Found in Veterans Exposed to Bombs
headline.main: Brain Ailments in Veterans Likened to Those in Athletes
headline.print_headline: Athletes’ Brain Disease Is Found in Veterans

docs.abstract: Dr Lee E Goldstein study in journal Science Translational Medicine finds that combat veterans exposed to roadside bombs in Iraq and Afghanistan suffer from chronic traumatic encephalopathy, invisible brain injury normally associated with football players and other athletes; findings could have profound implications for military policy, veterans programs and future research.
docs.snippet: The same degenerative brain disease found in football players and boxers has been found in veterans exposed to roadside bombs, a finding with potentially profound implications.
